name: aras
text:
The Bazaar of Menzoberranzan attracts merchants and buyers from across the multiverse. Most races are welcome (with the exception of beholders, neogi and githyanki), and as long as the peace is kept and proper respect are shown to the laws and customs of Menzoberranzan, someone (or something) could buy whatever they might have desired here (including cadavers, slaves, dresses, opiates, weapons, poisons, explosives). Many surface-dwelling merchants and trade goods pass through or stay in Menzoberranzan. All people of Menzoberranzan shop at the Bazaar

In the Bazaar are cobblers, leatherworkers, street food, she-beens, opium dens, aphrodisiac sellers, riding lizards, duergar, kuo-toa, and ogre mages. Slaves running on errands includ orcs, gnolls, bugbears, goblins, and kobolds. There are barber stalls, game tents, and a portrait painter. One could obtain surgery or send messages to the surface from the Bazaar. There are also performers, acrobats, fire eaters, magicians, and even bards telling stories on its busy streets. Anyone publically insulting a noble drow house, or badmouthing the Duergar Emperor, will be arrested.

The Bazaar smells of surface produce, mulled wine, leather, frying oil, rothe dung, and blood.

Organization

No permanent structures were allowed within the accepted limits of the Bazaar by order of the council. Places of business were to move at least every 66 days, so as to prevent monopolies on space and promote browsing, and to prevent the noble houses from making the Bazaar a battleground of real estate, often making finding a particular stall very difficult. Guides are available, the fancier noble ones call themselves factors and know who to know in the Bazaar.  Trainee drow wizards, clerics, and warriors, in groups of 8-12 from Tier Breche, once patrolled the Bazaar, they provided firm, yet unobtrusive law enforcement. Now though, duergar patrols loyal to the Emperor provide a much more bribable law enforcement, allowing some tents to remain put for longer than the allowed time. Still bribery is officially illegal, and any Drow of a house can threaten the duergar.

Prices are always fluctuating due to supply and demand. Despite (or perhaps because of) the patrols, the Bazaar was home to many unlicensed and illicit activities.
